Having both sets of classes in the primordial class loader *and* trying 
to have them loaded dynamically by a custom class loader is cruisin' 
for trouble.

Presumably your custom class loaders do things the "normal" way, i.e. 
defer to the parent/primordial class loader prior to loading a class.  
If the normal behavior of your app is that the primordial/parent class 
loader *doesn't* have access to both sets of classes, then your testing 
environment isn't representative of your runtime environment.

You should consider running those class loader tests that explicitly 
check class loading behavior separately from the bulk of the tests 
which are checking your classes, if you absolutely *must* have both 
sets of classes in the default class loader.  Alternatively, you could 
set the context class loader for *most* of your tests to include both 
classes, while that of the class loading tests would omit them.  The 
key is to avoid those classes *ever* being loaded by the primordial 
class loader.

You can certainly write a class loader that *doesn't* delegate loading 
to the parent/primordial, but that path is fraught with exceptions and 
errors (of the ClassCast and Linkage types) and painstaking to get 
exactly right.


On Sep 21, 2004, at 10:00 AM, Russell Gold wrote:

>
> Does anybody have a good way to test behavior that depends on code in
> different classloaders communicating? That is, we have a client that
> should only use the classes in one jar talking to a server that should
> only use the classes in another jar. It is trivial to test the
> communications if I smush the classpaths together, but I want a
> sensible way to restrict each of the parts to its own classloader,
> preferably without preventing the suite from having both sets of
> classes in its *default* classloader...
